creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: The terrestrial gradient study at Coweeta compares vegetation, soils, and understory microclimate of five sites: 118 low elevation (782 m) pine-oak, 218 low elevation (795 m) cove hardwood, 318 low elevation (865 m) mixed oak, 427 high elevation (1001 m) mixed oak, 527 high elevation (1347 m) northern hardwood. Understory microclimate stations were installed in representative locations at the downslope margin of each 20 x 40 m gradient plot (within the 80 x 80 m plot).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Overall bounding box describing the geographic region within the Coweeta LTER study domain represented in data set 1013, based on the maximum geographic extents of all site polygons referenced in the data set

section.title: Q/A-Q/C from 2009 to Present
section.para:
Beginning in 2009, Data were imported into Matlab as raw DAT files. Using Georgia Coastal Ecosystems (GCE) data toolbox created by GCE Information Manager Wade Sheldon, data were plotted and examined for irregularities. To assist in flagging irregular data, "bounds" were created for the data. If data exceeded these pre-defined bounds, then the data were flagged for further scrutiny. Note that flagged data does not necessarily mean the data is bad, just that it exceeds "normal" values and should be examined further. The following criteria were used to flag data:
airtemp – If temperature >40°C or <-40°C, then flagged as "I" (Impossible); if temperature >30°C or <-30°C, then flagged as "Q" (Questionable)
soilt05 – If temperature >40°C or <-30°C, then flagged as "I" (Impossible); if temperature >30°C or <-20°C, then flagged as "Q" (Questionable)
soilt20 – If temperature >40°C or <-20°C, then flagged as "I" (Impossible); if temperature >30°C or <-10°C, then flagged as "Q" (Questionable)
soilt50 – If temperature >40°C or <-20°C, then flagged as "I" (Impossible); if temperature >30°C or <-15°C, then flagged as "Q" (Questionable)
soilmois – If soil moisture >0.7 or <0.01, then flagged as "I" (Impossible); if soil moisture >0.6 or <0.05, then flagged as "Q" (Questionable)

section.title: Overall Field Collection Method
section.para:
All variables are collected with a Campbell Scientific, Inc. automated data logger - Model CR10. Air temperature and relative humidity sensors (Campbell Model 207) are exposed approximately 1.3 m above the forest floor. Soil temperature sensors are buried at 5 cm, 20 cm, and 50 cm below the soil-leaf litter interface by inserting sensor into the undisturbed sidewall of a small pit. Soil temperatures were originally collected with Model 107 thermistor sensors, later replaced with thermocouples constructed from 18 gage copper-constantan wire. Soil temperature sensors at 50 cm were added October, 2000. Water content measurements at the Top (0-30 cm and 30-60 cm) and Bottom (0-30 cm and 30-60 cm) commenced March 1999. Stored data are copied from the logger approximately every 14-30 days.
After 2001, relative humidity, air temperature, and soil temperature manual observations were discontinued.

methodStep.instrumentation: Campbell Scientific Model 10TCRT Thermocouple Reference; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific (model: 10TCRT)
Air Temp & Humidity Sensor; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific (model: 207)
Campbell Data Logger; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific (model: CR-10)
Campbell Scientific CS615 Water Content Reflectometer; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific (model: CS615)
Campbell Scientific Model 107 Thermistor; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific (model: 107 Thermistor)

section.title: Pre 2001 QA/QC
section.para:
Prior to 2001 the following QAQC procedures were used for air temperature and soil temperature:
Air Temperature: Minimum and maximum air temperatures recorded by the datalogger over a 2-4 week period are compared to a maximum/minimum thermometer installed below the sensor. If discrepancies of >2 degrees C occur, the thermometer is replaced. Following this, if the discrepancy continues, the sensor is replaced.
Soil Temperature: Soil temperatures recorded using thermocouples wired to a datalogger are compared to readings taken using a REOTEMP soil thermometer. Because these measurements cannot be taken in exactly the same location, identical temperatures are not expected. If the thermometer readings are consistently higher or lower at one location than the thermocouple measurement, the thermocouple is replaced.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site ULTRB -- Upper Little Tennessee River Basin, North Carolina, USA. The Upper Little Tennessee Watershed Basin is a primary focus for The Coweeta LTER's regional ecological and socio-ecological research.

CWT Study Site WS18 -- Watershed 18 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Grady Branch Watershed. The first hydrologic records for this site began on 7/03/1936. The weir type for this watershed is a 120 degree V-notch. This is a control watershed that has been undisturbed since 1927.

CWT Study Site WS27 -- Watershed 27 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Hard Luck Creek Watershed. The first hydrologic records from this watershed date to 11/02/1946. The weir is a 120 degree V notch. This a control watershed, but it was partially defoliated by fall cankerworm infestations from 1972 to 1979.

section.title: Terrestrial Gradient Microclimate Study
section.para: Study were placed on an elevational gradient that is designed to represent the variation present with the southern Appalachian study area.
This project is designed to collect fine-scale base microclimate data for modeling projects focused on tree growth, tree recruitment, tree respiration, and soil biogeochemistry cycling.

All variables are collected with a Campbell Scientific, Inc. automated data logger - Model CR10. Air temperature and relative humidity sensors (Campbell Model 207) are exposed approximately 1.3 m above the forest floor. Soil temperature sensors are buried at 5 cm, 20 cm, and 50 cm below the soil-leaf litter interface by inserting sensor into the undisturbed sidewall of a small pit. Soil temperatures were originally collected with Model 107 thermistor sensors, later replaced with thermocouples constructed from 18 gage copper-constantan wire. Soil temperature sensors at 50 cm were added October, 2000. Water content measurements at the Top (0-30 cm and 30-60 cm) and Bottom (0-30 cm and 30-60 cm) commenced March 1999. Stored data are copied from the logger approximately every 14-30 days.

abstract.para: The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles. The current interdisciplinary research integrates ecological and socioeconomic components across 54,000 km2 of the southern Appalachian Mountains, a biogeophysical and socioeconomic region in which evolutionary and historical processes converge (Whittaker 1956, Markusen 1987, Barnes 1991, Kretzschmar et al. 1993, Bailey 1996). Our research objective in 2002-2008 is to advance scientific understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. Our guiding hypothesis is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in response to socioeconomic and biogeophysical conditions with consequences that cascade through ecosystems.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number OCE-9982133. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.
